Award.AwardTitle: Hybrid Numerical Methods for Three-Phase Flows with Moving Contact Lines
Award.AbstractNarration:
Multiphase flows that involve both solid bodies and fluid interfaces are ubiquitous in many applications such as particle-stabilized emulsions, flotation technology, and animal locomotion at fluid interfaces. These applications play important roles in the mining industry, micro- and nanotechnologies, biotechnology, and environmental science. For example, nanoparticles may self-assemble on a fluid interface due to capillary forces; this effect can be used in the fabrication of nanostructured materials. Dry water, a water-in-air emulsion stabilized by silica nanoparticles, has demonstrated extraordinary capability to absorb carbon dioxide and is potentially useful in the war against global warming. Flotation techniques, where gas bubbles are used to remove suspended particles, have been widely used in wastewater treatment. This project aims to develop numerical tools for detailed studies of these complex flows and to resolve fundamental questions that arise in applications. The project will also provide hands-on training opportunities for graduate students to work in interdisciplinary research.

The goal of this project is to develop hybrid numerical methods for the direct numerical simulation of flow problems where deformable fluid interfaces, moving rigid particles, and moving contact lines coexist. An arbitrary Lagrangian-Eulerian (ALE) algorithm on an unstructured adaptive moving mesh will be adopted to track the moving boundaries of rigid particles. Two interface-capturing methods based on the same moving mesh, namely the phase-field and the level set methods, will be developed to capture the deformation of fluid interfaces as well as the moving contact lines. These hybrid ALE-interface-capturing methods combine the advantages of both components: the ALE method provides an accurate representation of the particle surface, which is critical for delicate contact-line conditions; the interface-capturing methods easily handle the topological transitions of fluid interfaces. In particular, the ALE-phase-field approach satisfies an energy law and is essentially free of parasitic currents. Finite-element software packages will be developed to implement the proposed methods. This work will advance the development of numerical algorithms for different types of moving boundary problems and also enrich the understanding of contact-line dynamics in complex systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Contact-line dynamics coupled with moving solid bodies plays an important role in many natural phenomena and industrial applications, such as water-walking insects, Pickering emulsions, and froth flotation. The contact line here refers to the intersection between a fluid interface and a solid surface. This problem is challenging due to the stress singularity at the moving contact line and the co-existence of difference types of moving boundaries, i.e., the deformable fluid interface and the rigid solid particle. In practice, this problem is further complicated by contact angle hysteresis because most solid surfaces are intrinsically rough and/or chemically heterogeneous. For example, raindrops may stick to vertical glass windows without sliding due to hysteresis. In this NSF sponsored research, we developed different numerical methods for the direct numerical simulation of interfacial flows involving moving contact lines and moving particles. The primary outcomes can be summarized as follows.

(1) We developed an arbitrary-Lagrangian-Eulerian-phase-field method for the contact line dynamics on moving particles, where the particles are tracked by the moving mesh and the fluid interfaces are captured by the phase-field method. In our variational approach, the hydrodynamic forces and moments between the particles and the surrounding fluids exactly cancel out, which leads to improved numerical stability. Our simulations successfully reproduced the Cheerios effect (attractive capillary interactions between floating particles) and the transient process of solid particles impacting a liquid surface.

(2) We developed a thermodynamically consistent phase-field model for contact angle hysteresis. Starting from free energies in the two-phase system, we derived a phase-field model that automatically captures the advancing, receding, and pinning of contact lines. Furthermore, this model is consistent with the second law of thermodynamics and recovers the dissipation due to hysteresis.

(3) We developed an interface-preserving level-set method for the moving contact line problem. Firstly, we designed a discontinuous Galerkin method for level-set reinitialization, which preserves the interface and thus greatly improves the mass conservation in level-set simulations. Secondly, we investigated the generalized Navier boundary condition (GNBC) in the level-set method and provided guidelines for the choice of numerical parameters for predictive simulations. Finally, motivated by the phase-field model for contact angle hysteresis, we incorporated hysteresis into the GNBC. This new boundary condition can be easily extended to a broader class of sharp-interface methods for interfacial flows.

The intellectual merit of this research lies in the fact that our phase-field based methods satisfy physically consistent energy laws, which on the one hand is a necessary condition for the faithful description of the real physics and on the hand may be used to guide the design of robust energy-stable numerical schemes. The ideas in the phase-field method were also used in the treatment of contact lines in the level-set method.

In terms of broader impact, this research provided training opportunities to two undergraduate students, one graduate student, and two visiting graduate students. This research has potential impacts on many areas such as mining industry, food industry, micro- and nanotechnologies, biomimetics, and global warming. It will also promote the education of the general audience on the understanding of interesting physical phenomena in our everyday life, e.g., walking of water spiders, the Cheerios effect, and water splash formation.
